summary: The study identifies a new pathway for keramamide biosynthesis in Theonella swinhoei WA, revealing a unique flavin-dependent halogenase with broad substrate specificity.
key_claims: Identified a new gene cluster from the metagenome of uncultured bacteria associated with Theonella swinhoei WA for keramamide biosynthesis.
Discovered a unique flavin-dependent halogenase with potential as a useful biocatalytic tool.

reaction_types.name: halogenation
reaction_types.context: of natural products in the study

_title: An Unusual Flavin-Dependent Halogenase from the Metagenome of the Marine Sponge Theonella swinhoei WA
_abstract: Uncultured bacteria from sponges have been demonstrated to be responsible for the generation of many potent, bioactive natural products including halogenated metabolites.  1  The identification of gene clusters from the metagenomes of such bacterial communities enables the discovery of enzymes that mediate new and useful chemistries and allows insight to be gained into the biogenesis of potentially pharmacologically important natural products. Here we report a new pathway to the keramamides (krm); the first functional evidence for the existence of a distinct producer in the Theonella(swinhoei WA chemotype is revealed, and a key enzyme on the pathway, a unique flavin dependent halogenase with a broad substrate specificity, and with potential as a useful new biocatalytic tool is described.
